ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned from this course how to do fieldwork, more specifically how to form elicitation questions, how to take elicitation notes, and how to perform analysis based on fieldwork data.

fast transcription of unfamiliar language, fast hypothesis development and testing, interpersonal skills for working with language consultant, flexibility/adaptability in the face of unexpected research impediments

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really wish that our second and third consultants could have been native speakers of Pashto.

strengths: good balance between freedom to explore research questions, and individual guidance in exploring those questions. excellent, in-depth, quick feedback on assignments

weaknesses: it was sometimes hard to stay engaged when other students were asking the consultant questions for their own research, and the discussion was not clearly relevant to my own interests

also, not anyone's fault, but it was difficult having three different consultants throughout the semester. if any other steps could be taken to increase commitment/strength of relationship with consultant, that would be beneficial

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to my classmates, not only because this course satisfies both language and methodology requirements in the linguistics department, but mostly because the setting of the course in general is fun, and we can get a chance to work with a language that is not so easy to access otherwise.

I would recommend this course to a student who is interested in conducting their own fieldwork, or in learning about what's involved in fieldwork. it was a lot of work, and the learning outcomes are more practical than intellectual: how to interact with a consultant, how to transcribe quickly, how to deal with real (noisy) language production data. perhaps more than other courses, you get out of this course what you put into it: great for someone interested in developing fieldwork skills, maybe not so great for someone with less personal drive towards this field
